content.text:
# List of military operations in the Nordic countries during World War II

The following is a list of military operations conducted in Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Greenland during World War II.
Axis
* Birke ("Birch") (1944) 20px — German plan to withdraw from northern Finland prior to the Lapland War
* Birkhahn (1945) 20px — German evacuation from Norway.
* Büffel ("Buffalo") (1940) 20px — German operation to relieve troops in Narvik, Norway
* Hokki ("Calk") (1944)  — Finnish plan to destroy railroad tracks to deny the Soviets their supplies.
* Holzauge ("Wood knot") (1942) 20px — activities in Greenland
* Ikarus (1940) 20px — planned German invasion of Iceland in response to British Operation Fork
* Juno (1940) 20px — German naval operation to disturb allied supplies to Norway
* Kilpapurjehdus ("Regatta") (1941)  — Finnish naval operation for the militarization of the Åland islands.
* Lachsfang (1942) 20px 20px — Proposed combined German and Finnish attack against Kandalaksha and Belomorsk
* Nordlicht 2 ("Aurora Borealis") (1944) 20px — German withdrawal from the Kola Peninsula into Norway
* Silberfuchs ("Silver Fox") (1941) 20px 20px — German and Finnish operations in the Arctic, including:
** Blaufuchs 1 ("Blue Fox 1") (1941) 20px — Staging of German forces from Germany to northern Finland
** Blaufuchs 2 ("Blue Fox 2") (1941) 20px — Staging of German forces from Norway to northern Finland
** Platinfuchs ("Platinum Fox") (1941) 20px 20px — Joint German-Finnish attack towards Murmansk from Finnish Petsamo
** Polarfuchs ("Polar Fox") (1941) 20px 20px — Joint German-Finnish attack towards Kandalaksha from Finnish Lapland
** Renntier ("Reindeer") (1941) 20px — German occupation of Petsamo
*Safari (1943) 20px — German operation to capture and disarm Danish forces
* Sizilien (1943) 20px — German raid upon Allied-occupied Spitzbergen (Svalbard)
* Tanne Ost (1944) 20px — failed German attempt to capture Suursaari from Finland
* Tanne West (1944) 20px — planned German attempt to capture the Åland from Finland
* Weserübung ("Weser Exercise") (1940) 20px — German invasion of Denmark and Norway
** Weserübung Nord ("Weser Exercise") (1940) 20px — German invasion of Trondheim and Narvik
** Weserübung Sud ("Weser Exercise") (1940) 20px — German invasion of Bergen, Kristiansand, and Oslo
* Zitronella ("Lemon flavour") (1943) 20px — alternate name for Operation Sizilien
Allies
* Alphabet (1940)  — evacuation of British troops from Norway
* Apostle (1945)  — SAS operation to enforce German surrender in Norway
* Archery (1941) 20px — British commando raid on Vågsøy, Norway
* Anklet (1941) 20px 20px — raid on German positions on Lofoten Islands, Norway
* Brandy (1943) 20px 20px — MTB and commando raid on Florø, Norway
* Carthage (1945) 20px — RAF bombing of the Gestapo headquarters in Copenhagen, Denmark
* Cartoon (1943) 20px 20px — commando raid on the island of Stord near Leirvik, Norway
* Catherine (1939) 20px British plan to gain control of Baltic Sea
* Claymore (1941) 20px — British raid on Lofoten Islands, Norway
* Crackers (1943) 20px — British raid at Sognefjord, Norway
* Doomsday (1945)  — alternative name for Apostle
* Freshman (1942 20px) — attempted raid on a Norwegian heavy water plant at Vemork, see Gunnerside
** Grouse (1942) 20px — Norwegian guide party for Freshman
* Gunnerside (1943) 20px — 2nd raid on the Norwegian heavy water plant at Vemork
*Fork (1940) 20px — Invasion of Iceland by British.
* Gauntlet (1941) 20px  20px — raid on Spitzbergen
* Jupiter (1942) 20px — suggested invasion of Norway
* Kitbag (1941) 20px — aborted commando raid on town of Florø in Norway
* Leader (1943) 20px 20px — American/British Home Fleet raid on German shipping along the coast of Norway in the Bodø area
* Musketoon (1942) 20px 20px — British/ Norwegian destruction of a power station in Norway
* R 4 (1940) 20px — Planned British invasion of Norway
* Source (1943) 20px 20px — British response to German operation Sizilien
* The Sepals/Perianth Operation (1944) — OSS supported operation in Sweden
* Sunshine (1944) 20px 20px — Combined British/Norwegian operation to protect essential power installations against possible German scorched earth tactics towards the end of the war
* Valentine (1940) 20px — British occupation of the Faroe Islands
* Wilfred (1940) 20px — British plan to mine the Norwegian coast
Other
* Rädda Danmark ("Save Denmark") (1945) 20px — Swedish plan to liberate Denmark before the German surrender
** Rädda Själland ("Save Zealand") (1945) 20px — planned Swedish landings on Zealand
** Rädda Bornholm ("Save Bornholm") (1945) 20px — planned Swedish landings on Bornholm
See also
* List of World War II military operations
References
Further reading
* Dear, Ian. The Oxford companion to world war II (New York: Oxford University Press, 1995)
* Elting, John R. Battles for Scandinavia (Time-Life Books 1981)
* Haarr, Geirr. The Gathering Storm: Naval War in Northern Europe, September 1939 to April 1940 (2013)
* Haarr, Geirr.  German Invasion of Norway: April 1940 (vol 1 2012); The Battle for Norway, April-June 1940 (vol 2 2010)
* Mann, Chris. British Policy and Strategy Towards Norway, 1941-45 (Palgrave Macmillan, 2012)
* Miller, James. The North Atlantic Front: Orkney, Shetland, Faroe and Iceland at War (2004)
* Nissen, Henrik S., ed. Scandinavia during the Second World War (Universitetsforlaget, 1983)
* Petrow,  Richard. The Bitter Years; The Invasion and Occupation of Denmark and Norway, April 1940-May 1945 (1974)
* Riste,  Olav et al. Norway and the Second World War (1996)
* Stenius, H., Österberg, M. and Östling, J., eds. Nordic Narratives of the Second World War: National Historiographies Revisited (Lund: Nordic Academic Press, 2011).
* Vehvilainen, Olli. "Scandinavian Campaigns." in A Companion to World War II (2012) ed. by Thomas W. Zeiler and Daniel M. DuBois : vol 1 pp 208–21.
* Vehvilainen, Olli.  Finland In The Second World War: Between Germany and Russia (2002) [https://www.amazon.com/Finland-Second-World-War-Between/dp/0333801490/ excerpt and text search]
ca:Operacions de la Segona Guerra Mundial#Escandinàvia
